Hi Everyone, 

I've spoken to Derek James (who runs this group) about this =
issue, 
and he suggested I bring it up for discussion.  So please feel free=
 
to share your thoughts.

I have come to the conclusion that opening the a=
rchives to public 
viewing was probably not the best idea in retrospect.  T=
here is one 
good motivation for doing so, which is that it makes them 
pot=
entially searchable from outside engines.  However, on balance I 
believe i=
t is now apparent after we have run this experiment for a 
couple months th=
at this benefit is outweighed by the downsides:

In particular I think open=
ing the archives has significantly 
deterred non-members from joining the g=
roup.  The surface-level 
effect of this deterrence is simply that the grou=
p grows less 
quickly.  However, there is a more concerning secondary effec=
t, 
which is that when you do not join, you are less likely to post even 
i=
f you have something worth contributing, because it would require 
joining =
to do so.  Therefore, the net effect is stagnant growth and 
a general sque=
lching of broader discussion and fresh new input from 
outside.

I also bel=
ieve there is a more subtle tertiary effect on existing 
members, which is =
that now that you don't need to log into yahoo to 
view the latest messages=
, you are more likely not to post something 
that you think of offhand, bec=
ause that would require logging in.  
In the past, since you had to log in =
in order to view the archives, 
you were already logged in once ideas poppe=
d into your head, but now 
you are likely not logged in, and therefore it i=
sn't worth going to 
the trouble just to make a casual point.  I know that =
I have found 
even myself falling into that kind of pattern and not posting=
 since 
I wasn't logged in.  Again, the net effect is muting discussion. 

=
The statistics appear to back up this theory.  Of course, statistics 
prove=
 correlation and not causality, but the argument for causality 
is strenghe=
ned by the precise alignment between the time that we 
opened the archives =
and the time that membership growth and posting 
suddenly plummeted.  Here =
are the numbers:

New Members by Month
--------------------
Oct: 11
Nov: 14=

Dec: 5
Jan: 4
Feb: 3 (so far)

New Posts by Month

Oct: =
76

Both statistics show a sudden =
and dramatic drop right at December, 
right about when we opened the archiv=
es.  That seems to support the 
idea that doing so had a negative effect on=
 overall participation.  
Of course there are other possible explanations s=
uch as the natural 
ebb and flow of discourse or just a general downward tr=
end as people 
change interests, but the coincidental correlation in timing=
 makes 
it likely that even if those are true, they probably are not the 
o=
nly contributing factors.

My view is that this group is first and foremost=
 a discussion group, 
and only secondarily a reference site.  It's nice to =
be able to 
search for old discusison, but what we're really here for is to=
 
interact with each other in the present.  Therefore, it doesn't make 
sen=
se to sacrifice the interactive quality for a slightly more 
convenient ref=
erence, at least in my opinion.

So I am recommending we close the archives=
 to the public again and 
return to our old system.  However, since we have=
 been genuinely a 
thriving community for several years now (just look at m=
ost yahoo 
groups and we are almost unmatched in consistent quality content=
 and 
friendly discussion), it is only right to let everyone have their 
tw=
o cents before such a decision is made, so we can decide together 
rather t=
han make a unilateral decision.  Derek will ultimately

ased on your input.  If no one has input, it will

en myself and Derek, which is fine, but this

ipate.
